meanings.definition: To divide or cause to divide into two sharply contrasting groups or sets of opinions or beliefs.
meanings.sent1: The debate polarized the audience, with some strongly supporting one side and others firmly backing the other.
meanings.sent2: The controversial issue polarized the community, leading to heated arguments and divided loyalties.
meanings.sent3: The family dinner conversation about politics quickly polarized into two opposing camps, making dessert a tense affair.
meanings.sent4: Her bold statement on social media polarized her followers, causing a wave of unfollows and passionate responses.
meanings.sent5: The decision to change the school uniform policy polarized the students, creating a clear divide between those in favor and those against.

meanings.definition: To restrict the vibrations of (a transverse wave, especially light) wholly or partially to one direction.
meanings.sent1: The special sunglasses polarized the sunlight, reducing glare and making everything clearer.
meanings.sent2: The polarized lenses in his glasses helped him see better in bright sunlight by blocking out horizontal light waves.
meanings.sent3: She jokingly claimed that her polarized sunglasses were so effective that they made her see the world in black and white.
meanings.sent4: The scientist explained how polarized light waves behave like a team of synchronized dancers, moving in perfect harmony.
meanings.sent5: The photographer used a polarized filter to capture the vibrant colors of the sunset, enhancing the beauty of the scene.
